awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Sea-level rise, coastal wetland expansion, and proglacial lake contributions to abrupt increases in northern atmospheric CH4 during the last deglaciation
awd_abstract_narration:
This multidisciplinary research seeks to understand the timing, magnitude, and overall contribution of newly flooded land areas in the northern hemisphere to rapid increases in atmospheric methane concentrations during the last deglaciation (18-8 ka). Polar ice core records reveal dynamic increases in atmospheric methane concentrations during this period, but the source of this methane remains the subject of much debate. This study will measure the isotopic values of methane emissions from field samples to provide region-specific estimates of methane emissions from coastal wetlands, peatlands, proglacial lakes, and other lake types (e.g. thermokarst and post-glacial lakes) since the last deglaciation for comparisons with ice core records. This research will reconstruct the past methane emissions from flooded deglacial land areas (potentially representing unknown northern sources of increased atmospheric methane concentrations during these periods) and assess their role in contributing to the abrupt methane increases observed in in polar ice core records. Knowledge of past methane emissions from newly inundated land areas flooded by sea level rise, wetland expansion, permafrost thaw, and associated lake formation will provide an improved understanding of global climate feedbacks that will likely accelerate in the region. This knowledge is critical to answering larger societal questions about the role of northern systems in global environmental change and our ability to understand the cascade of effects from sea level rise and coastal flooding.

This research uses comprehensive paleoecological records of (a) northern continental shelf areas and coastal wetlands inundated by rapid deglacial sea-level rise (SLR) and (b) proglacial lake areas inundated by glacier and ice-sheet melt to document their past contributions to abrupt increases in atmospheric methane concentrations. The research goals are to: (1) synthesize new and existing shelf, coastal wetland, regional SLR curves, and proglacial-lake initiation data to reconstruct newly inundated areas poleward of 30? N; (2) estimate past methane flux from inundated northern coastal regions as they evolved from methane-consuming forest and grassland areas to higher emitting mudflats, marshes, and freshwater wetlands by integrating new and existing methane fluxes into an empirical model; (3) analyze new and existing methane fluxes from proglacial lakes of different sizes, ages and geographies to build an empirical model for reconstructing proglacial lake emissions from 18 ka to present (with an emphasis on the deglacial period,18-8 ka); (4) use stable isotopes (∂13C, ∂D) of methane and 14C dating to constrain the magnitude and timing of methane flux from these newly flooded land areas; and (5) compare our reconstructions of past methane emissions and isotope fluxes from inundated shelves, coastal wetlands, and proglacial lakes with global atmospheric methane constraints based on recent, higher resolution data of methane isotopes (∂13C, ∂D, 14C) from Greenland and Antarctic ice cores using atmospheric box modeling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report (NSF Grant # 1903623) 

Title: Collaborative Research: Sea-level rise, coastal wetland expansion, and proglacial lake contributions to abrupt increases in northern atmospheric CH4 during the last deglaciation

Lead PI: Katey Walter Anthony (Univ. of Alaska at Fairbanks)

Co-I: Steve Frolking (Univ. of New Hampshire; Award 1903623)

Report Submission Period:  09/1/2019 - 08/31/2023

When the most recent ice age was at its maximum (called the Last Glacial Maximum), roughly 20,000 years ago, large ice sheets covered much of northern North America and Eurasia. Because so much water was locked into these ice sheets, global mean sea level was about 120 meters lower than today.  This shifted coastlines seaward and exposed large land areas that are now inundated by the ocean. As a result, there was a continuous land ‘bridge’ connecting Alaska and Eastern Siberia, which are now separated by the Bering Strait. This area is known as Beringia. A key focus of this project was to estimate the potential contribution of the Beringian landscape to atmospheric methane concentrations over the past 20,000 years. Since the Last Glacial Maximum sea-level rise has led to widespread flooding of Beringia by the rising Arctic and Pacific Oceans. A terrestrial area larger than Greenland gradually became inundated, transforming first into a coastal and then a marine environment (Figure 1). During this transition, large regions became methane emitting coastal wetlands, but the magnitude of potential methane fluxes from these wetlands had not been assessed. This study estimated the size of coastal wetlands for Beringia for the past 20,000 years and estimated past methane fluxes from this region.

This study combined present-day analogs (CH4 flux data and an Alaska wetland map) with an extensive GIS paleo-analysis to estimate the magnitude of potential CH4 fluxes from Beringian coastal wetlands in the past. A field campaign was conducted during the summer of 2021 on the Kenai Peninsula in Alaska to measure methane fluxes along a series of coastal transects. A second field campaign to measure coastal fluxes near Kotzebue, Alaska was cancelled due to Covid-19 pandemic restrictions. These methane flux data were combined with other published coastal wetland methane flux data to generate characteristic flux rates, with uncertainty, for several coastal wetland types (saltwater tidal, seasonally flooded, irregularly flooded, (semi-)permanently flooded). To scale these emissions to Beringia, the extent of coastal wetlands was based on a detailed GIS analysis including multiple data sets. First, published paleo-ocean depth data were used to estimate the timing of flooding. This was validated by comparing to published ages of inundated terrestrial sediments from Beringia. Then the coastal wetland area was estimated and classified with the present-day wetland map of coastal Alaska wetlands to scale up the flux data to the region. We estimated Beringian methane fluxes of up to 3.5 billion kilograms of methane per year, with peak emissions about 15,000 years ago, when emissions from other northern wetlands were smaller than this (they are now much larger, primarily due to northern wetland area expansion through the Holocene).

Other project research was published quantifying (i) the influence of high-latitude wetland expansion and successional processes on methane emissions during the Holocene (past ~12,000 years), (ii) the influence of pan-arctic lakes on early Holocene warming due to deglacial release of methane, and (iii) spatio-temporal patterns of northern lake formation since the Last Glacial Maximum.

Graduate student and early-career researchers were trained in this project, and the project enhanced opportunities for women in biogeochemistry research. These researchers have had the opportunity to learn state-of-the art field and laboratory measurement and simulation modeling techniques, and to develop their own scientific studies within the context of the larger project. All wrote and presented their research in theses, national and international conferences, as well as peer-reviewed scientific publications. We have disseminated the results of the research at conferences in North America and Europe, collaborating with other teams of scientists, and in the peer-reviewed scientific literature.

Modified by: Stephen E Frolking
